physDesc.p: The letter consists of 5 sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of the first four and on one side of the fifth. Each new sheet (every other page) has “R.A.” and a page number in the upper left corner and the date in the upper right corner. The paper appears to have a very faint watermark, though it is not legible. In several places there are words crossed out and new words written above them in pen.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I got your letter of January 5th this morning, about your book, and immediately got hold of Brown. He is considerably hurt at your attitude, and I must say I think you go a little far in forbidding him to publish the book. The book will be out in a few days. I have corrected the final proofs. Brown is not crooked, I do not care what they tell you there. He is unbusinesslike, and procrastinating, and very poor. The only reason they can pay at all on the “Poetry Journal” is because Mrs. Blanch Schumaker Wagstaff [sic] gives them a little sum of money each month to pay contributors. They paid me three dollars for a poem I sent them, and I enclose a draft for five dollars, which they are paying you. I have also persuaded Brown to accept Flint’s “Chalfont Saint Giles,” also for three dollars, and he has agreed to pay the money in to me before the end of the month. They never pay until the poems are printed. He says he sent you five copies of the “Poetry Journal” which contained your poems, and I have no doubt he did, and you must put down not receiving them to the mails. I will see if I have a copy and send it to you at once; but he has also promised to send out to the Press and get some copies and send them to you.

His little series has some quite good people in it, and I think you will do as well to leave your book with him as anywhere else. If you take it away from him now, you should reimburse him for setting it up and for the various corrections on the proof. He had corrected one set before I saw it, and I have corrected two since. All of this means that he has to pay the printer. He does not demand this; on the contrary, I think he is quixotically fair, and as you will see by his letter to you, he is willing to give you back the book and himself pay for all the trouble and expense he has been in in regard to it – at least, so I understand his last paragraph, but I should not think that you would want to put him to any such expense. He is undoubtedly procrastinating, and I think it is even difficult for him to find the next dollar, but he is enthusiastic about your work, and will push it as far as his means allow.

I enclose the proof-sheets of his catalogue, containing an announcement of your book, and I sent him in Teignmouth Shore’s quotation about you from “Colour” to fill in the part of a page which on this proof is blank.

I have not peremptorily forbidden the publication of the book, as you have asked me to do, as I felt sure that when you received this cheque from him and got his letter, you would not want it suppressed. I do not want to hurt your feelings, but I do not think there will be any great sale for the book here, no matter who publishes it. It is not very easy to get our things sold in quantity, for the three hundred copies, which seems to make such an impression on you, would be a very small amount for America, and you must not forget that the price is exceedingly cheap. Booksellers over here do not care to handle such cheap books, as their percentages are not enough to make them worth while. Ferris Greenslet was doubtful when he got up the New Poetry Series whether he could get them handled at seventy-five cents, retail price. Before I suggested your book to Brown, I had offered it to Macmillan, Houghton Mifflin, Mitchell Kennerly, and Boni, and they all refused it. Brown alone was willing to take the risk, and although in most of this series Brown has been helped out by the author’s paying part of the publication price, in your case he is taking the risk himself. There is no doubt whatever that he is treating you fairly, even if he has not answered your letters. He has accepted your contract as amended by you, and that was fair. I do not think you have any cause to complain of his treatment, although I admit that he is late in getting out the book; but most of the rest of his series is already published, and yours will be by week after next at the farthest, possibly next week.

If I have done wrong in this, I hope you will excuse me. Perhaps I should have followed your letter absolutely and taken the book away from him. I did not do so because I did not think it was to your interest. I am sure there will be no difficulty whatever in collecting what is due to you. I am right on the spot, and I have told Brown that I shall be after him to pay you what he owes you, when he owes it to you, and my position here is such that no one would dare cheat, because they know I could easily go for a lawyer and call for an accounting. At the same time I am not particularly crazy to handle the job, if you do not like the way I am handling it; and if you prefer to take the matter entirely into your own hands and deal with Brown directly, taking your book away or leaving it with him as you think fit, I am perfectly willing, and shall not be in the least offended. The position of go-between is always unpleasant, but I am not usually considered a bad business woman, and I have done everything I can for your interests, and you may be sure I always shall. You told me to make what contract I saw fit with Brown, and you would abide by my ruling, and apparently now you wish to take matters into your own hands. I must tell you frankly that, if you take this book away from Brown now, I think you will be treating him unfairly, and I think your suspicions are unfounded. I know him, and the father of the girl to whom he is engaged is an intimate friend of my brother Percy’s. He is an astronomer, and they are good people, and you are in no sense in the hands of a charlatan in dealing with him, although of course you cannot expect the same businesslike methods and satisfactory procedure that you would with a larger firm. At the same time Brown accepted your book, it was a question of having him publish it, or not having it published, and it seemed to me it was better to have him publish it than nobody.

Now I have something to complain of in my turn, something much more serious than you have, for you and Flint together put me into a very awkward position. Sometime ago Flint sent me his very nice review of “Six French Poets,” telling me he had sent it to Harriet, but that if Harriet could not print it in her paper, would I send it to any American review that would take it, as he could not possibly get it into anything in England, “Poetry and Drama” having shut down, and you taking care of it in “The Egoist.” Harriet had already given the book to Mrs. Otto Freer for review. It was being reviewed in “The New Republic” by Elizabeth Sergeant, and the only other paper with which I have any permanent connection is “The Little Review.” I had that morning received a letter from Margaret Anderson, asking me to tell her of some one whom I thought would know enough to review it. I immediately sent her Flint’s review, with the request that she print it.

Now, having sent the review to me, Flint should certainly not have printed it anywhere else until he heard from me, as no editor likes to print a thing which has already appeared somewhere else. In spite of this, and I suppose with the kindest intentions in the world, you printed it in the January “Egoist.” Now that is particularly awkward, as I had already taken some of the sentence of that review and incorporated them in a folder which Macmillan is getting out about my book, giving Flint’s name and saying that they appeared in “The Little Review.” The folder has not yet been issued, but is in type, and unfortunately you saw it fit to leave out these very sentences in the “Egoist” copy. In view of this, I have had to write and apologize to Margaret Anderson, and at the same time beg her to swallow her pride and put in the review as she received it, otherwise I must suppress those folders. You see that Brown is not the only unbusinesslike person in the world.

Now here is another thing – I should like to know why you were so anxious to suppress the few extremely nice sentences which Flint put in his review. You did the same thing in Fletcher’s review of me last year. Now it is quite possible that Flint was willing to have these sentences taken out, but it was hardly courteous, after having sent me the review, to send in an expurgated copy in which all the sentences which were uncomplimentary were left in, and many that were complimentary, were taken out. I understand your critical faculty and your desire always to do say exactly what you think, and not something else; but when this theory is carried so far as to make it necessary for you to impose your opinions upon other people’s articles on my work, I resent it extremely. In fact, you have hurt me to the quick. I was annoyed the first time you did this, but I am far more annoyed now. I have done everything I can to get yours, and Hilda’s, and Flint’s work printed over here, and I have referred to it in almost every lecture I have given, and I have given a great many. It is owing to my pushing and advertising that the Imagist Anthology has gone as well as it has. It is owing to the interest in the Imagist Anthology that your books sell so much better than you or Monro expected. I have stinted myself in neither time nor energy to push the group along. That I have not succeeded in getting your poems more generally accepted in magazines is not my fault. I cannot force editors to take what they do not want, although I have forced Brown to take Flint’s “Chalfont Saint Giles” by telling him how highly I thought of the poem. You know how much I admire all your work; but of course there are things in it that I do not admire, but I do not go out of my way to tell them to people, and I certainly will would not delete anything complimentary to you, if I were running a magazine and anybody asked me to print anything of the sort. I have as high a moral sense in regard to criticism as you have, and it is for that reason that my article on you was not wholly complimentary. But it is one thing to write one’s self, and another to use the blue pencil upon complimentary remarks when they are said by somebody else.

I understood that you were going to write a review of my book yourself for the February number, and I suppose that you ran Flint’s in in January out of the kindness of your heart; but it would have been kind and more tactful if you had left in the things which he said which were especially agreeable, and more businesslike if you had ascertained, or Flint had ascertained, whether or not I had disposed of the review to any paper here, before printing it.

Now here is one thing which I must beg you to do, or rather not to do – please do not refer in “The Egoist” to Braithwaite’s “Anthology of Magazine Verse.” I know very well what you think about it, and of course in many ways I agree with you, in some ways I do not. But Braithwaite has been a good friend to us, and whatever we may think of his taste, it is not our business to knock him. Without him we could not have got nearly as far as we have. He would not have put in Hilda’s poem, had I not pointed it out to him, and dinned, and dinned, and dinned at him to make him see the beauties of her work, which is far beyond him. The Anthology has a wide circulation, is bought by all the schools, and as the public as a rule is inferior in knowledge, even to Braithwaite, to be in it or out of it makes some difference to one’s standing as a poet. If you come out with a review saying disagreeable things about his book, he will be seriously hurt. He will think I have not played fair, and he will be down upon all of us from now on. There is no reason for you to review this book, it is an American publication and is not issued in England, and I shall be very grateful to you if you will not mention it at all in the columns of “The Egoist." You have seen what effect Ezra’s jumping on the people who do not agree with him has. It has landed him nowhere. In trying to make people understand a new form of art, it is far better to persuade them than to hammer them; and you must have seen by the amount of space which we were accorded in the papers and magazines that my method is having an effect which Ezra’s never had. Remember another thing - I have given up a great deal of my time, which I have wanted for production, to pushing us as a group, and these lectures which I have been giving have taken an amount of time and energy which is incredible. I do not grudge it, and every lecture pushes us all, as I have been extremely careful to boost us all in them, but I should have done very little of this work on my own account, because it is no longer necessary. I am now preparing my second edition of my “Six French Poets,” which came out in November. The second edition is not called for yet, but the publishers tell me that there is no doubt that it will be very shortly, and they wish to prepare for the second edition now. It is a $2.50 book, and you can see what that means.

Now it is the greatest satisfaction to me to feel that we are really getting ahead, as I know we are. But I do want you to leave Braithwaite alone, and I do want you to feel that I have not been neglectful of your interests in regard to Brown. There will be no difficulty whatever in getting the copyright away from him, if at any time any other publisher wants it; or if you wish to re-acquire this, the expense will not be great. But with all my loyalty to you, I do not wish to get in wrong here with the various people who are inclined to be our friends, and you must allow my judgment in the matter of silence about Braithwaite’s book, at least, to stand. You will do as you please about Brown, but I sincerely think that you had better leave the matter as it stands now.

As the book is coming out so late, your first payment will be in August. If your payment is not forthcoming, or if there seems any reasonable doubt as to the payment’s being fair, I will insist upon seeing his books, if you wish me to do so. You have worked with me long enough now to know my honesty and fairness, and I think you can trust to it in all matters for the future, and whatever does not go right, you may be sure I will make right as far as it is in any one’s power to do so.

I wrote to Flint yesterday, and told him it was impossible that we should print “Evil.” Ferris Greenslet thinks it most inadvisable that it should appear in our volume, and my opinion about it has not materially changed since he expurgated it. The poem is unpleasant in the extreme, my chief reason against it being that it is very reminiscent of certain things in “Others,” and that, although of course I understand from what a different point of view Flint wrote it, the public is not so discerning. We will accept “Whitechapel,” as I wrote you, but under no circumstances will I agree to “Evil;” and even if you think it is a prejudice, I trust you will bow to it, as I have to your decision in regard to “Off the Turnpike."

I wish we could meet. All these things would be straightened out in five minutes if we did, but even with a few differences of opinion and little advices going back and forth, you must never suppose for a moment that anything I could do, or say, or think, means anything but extreme interest in us as a group. And as to friendship – what is the use of talking about a thing which is as self-evident to me as the air I breathe?

I dined with my brother Lawrence last night, and my sister, Mrs. Bowlker, was there. Her son-in-law is in Flanders fighting, and she has just come back from England, where she has been, taking her grandchildren over to bid their father good-bye before he went to the front. It would have done your heart good to hear the pro-Ally, fire-eating talk that went on there. The little group of people, of whom I am one, and which consists of all the best educated and cultivated people in our part of the country – I might almost say in America – are so strongly in favour of the Allies that one would think we are still a colony. I think my whole family would walk to the front with guns on their shoulders, if they could. So, you see, my remarks in my last letter were not personal, and I hope you understand that they merely referred to the public attitude necessary in dealing with people of different opinion.

postscript.label: P.S.
postscript.p: I am returning Storer’s book, which I have just got back from Brown. He does not want to publish it, and I thought it safer to get it and send it myself, rather than trust to his remembering to send it.

div.note: Aldington ultimately publishes his book, Images, Old and New (1916), with Edmund R. Brown's press, Four Seas.; ¶7 F.S. Flint's review of Six French Poets appeared in The Egoist, Vol. 3, No. 1 (January, 1916), pp. 9-10, as well as in The Little Review, Vol. 2, No. 10 (January-February, 1916), pp. 16-17.
